comments.text:
Do this: put your own 6 y.o. daughter in prison cell and keep her locked up

transparent contraption and make more tests. Upload the video on YT.﻿
comments.author: intezamable

comments.text:
Oh fuck off. That's a horrible parallel.
1) These birds are not younglings. They're adults. The human in your 
parallel should be an adult.
2) Prison cell? Where'd you get that? How do you know how the researchers 
treated the birds? If they were wild birds, then they were probably housed 
temporarily in captivity and then released once the experiment was done. 
That's not "locked up for good." If they were raised captive, then they 
were given proper care (food, shelter, enrichment, etc.) That's not akin to 
a prison. where the idea is to punish the prisoners.
3) Where the hell did you get the razor blade from? What?!
4) They didn't take the birds' favorite food away. They offered them food 
as a reward for completing the experiment.

You want a good parallel?
1) Take adult humans, and offer them free food if they can solve a puzzle.
2) Upload it to youtube.

comments.text:
The crow has ripped all it's feathers out because it's unhappy- I've seen 
that in a lot of domesticated birds; could be lack of attention and/or 
boredom, these birds have requirements that need filled. It can't be let 
outside due to the experiment/ the bird flu and lack of training on the 
birds/students part. Although I do want science to proceed, it makes me 
feel bad for the bird. ﻿

comments.text:
Pseudonaukowy filmik, gdzie wcześniej głodzonym ptakom każe się wykonywać 
idiotyczne czynności poniżej ich godności. Papuga ewidentnie źle żywiona ma 
przerośniętą górną część dzioba, gawron pozbawiony jest właściwego 
upierzenia na skutek stałego trzymania w klimatyzowanym pomieszczeniu. To 
niby-doświadczenie dowodzi mniej na temat inteligencji tych ptaków, niż 
można zobaczyć siedząc przez godzinę w parku przez nie odwiedzanym. Stan 
fizyczny ptaków dowodzi w 100% zarówno braku jakiejkolwiek inteligencji jak 
i totalnego pozbawienia empatii u autorów tego "doświadczenia naukowego", a 
bez tych dwóch cech niemożliwe jest nie tylko poznanie i zrozumienie 
zwierząt ale również wszelka rzetelna nauka. Typowe psedo-doświdczenie w 
celu legalnego zainkasowania grantów pieniężnych założonych w budżecie 
jakieś "naukowej" instytucji. Filmik ma wartość jako trop do odnalezienia i 
napiętnowania owej instytucji.

Show your intelligence - try to learn polish ;) !﻿

comments.author: juki0h

comments.text:
Not All animals have intelligence Atmasyon, And out of all animals that 
actually do possess some intelligence only a small number of those species 
are actually self aware. very few animals can actually be said to be truly 
sentient. Simply filming animals in the wild can only lead so far. to truly 
learn the full extent of an animals behaviour and intelligence you must 
have a proper research environment, " a lab" to carry out experiments. 
IACUC carefully controls ethical treatment.
comments.author: AcanLord

comments.text:
thank you AcanLord for conversing rather than cursing. please read results 
on google "experiments on animals" to have more info on the subject. i used 
to find what you are talking about logical, too. animals are as smart and 
sensitive as we are. i don't like things done to animals that i don't want 
done to me or any person. technology enables us to use cameras to observe 
animals in nature. we have a lot to learn about ourselves and nature, but 
more so respecting other life forms.
comments.author: Atmasyon Cu

comments.text:
They are not torturing them in any way, they not harmed, not forced, not 
punished if they fail, they just go about solving the problem because they 
know they will get a treat when they do, something wild ones do on a daily 
basis, so shut the fuck up. *Also, videos like these help the crows and 
such, since more people will respect them rather than hate them after 
seeing them, so if anything, they are doing well more good for crows as a 
whole, while doing nothing bad to the crow, win-win situation
comments.author: frogbear02

comments.text:
Atmasyon, Animal Behavioral science is important to our understanding of 
the limitations and extent of intelligence found in other species. it is 
not torture, and IACUC has very stringent control parameters for the 
treatment of animals used in this kind of research, they are not harmed. 
had it not been for this kind of research we would have never known that 
Reef squid actually have language and that Crows have problem solving 
abilities that rival that of primates.

comments.text:
Crows: - 4th smartest creature in the world - 2nd most capable when it 
comes to adaptation and tool usage - Proven to be the fastest evolving 
species (tied with rats and cockroaches, anything humans routinely try to 
kill just evolves smarter) - Able to mimic speech like a parrot. - Outlives 
most mammals - With flight, can easily escape bad climate. - Rare sense of 
Family - Facial recognition ability. - Ties with Octopi for the chosen 
species to inherit the earth after humans self-destruct.
comments.author: JBGargamel

comments.text: is theese a first attemptes for two of the them?
comments.author: nextme100

comments.text:
Yeah, even the dullest of humans, barring damage or developmental issues, 
possesses exceptional intelligence in comparison to other species. The 
capacity for (what is call an open communication system - permits the 
transmission of an unlimited number of ideas) language alone is a 
staggering achievement for any species. Current research suggests dolphins 
might have an open communication system, like our language. The deployment 
is probably VERY different, however.
comments.author: JoeNietzsche

comments.text:
You're not considering the anatomical differences between us and them. 
Humans, being bipedal have two limbs completely free from locomotion 
requirements - these limbs are, essentially, dedicated to the function of 
environmental manipulation. Even apes must rely on their forelimbs for 
locomotion most of the time. Using technology as an intelligence marker is 
deeply flawed reasoning. This isn't to say that our accomplishments aren't 
impressive. They are but don't be myopic about it.
comments.author: JoeNietzsche

the case today but would it be if we had those senses?

comments.author: rebelrdie1776

comments.text:
So you're saying this bird is stimulated and is therefore a picture of 
health? Watch the vid again, you can see the plucking deteriation. I know 
that birds pluck for a variety of reasons - boredom, stress, vitamin 
deficiency and allergies etc, but has anyone looked in to why this bird is 
plucking so severely? If the cause isn't remedied quickly, plucking can 
become a life habit. And if no-one is looking in to it, then they don't 
give a rats left about the bird, it's just an experimental object.

comments.text:
actually, plucking is something birds do when they are bored too, not just 
stressed. Giving puzzles to solve is really good for crows and ravens. In 
zoos, to keep their crows and ravens healthy and stimulated, they sometimes 
hide the food or give them puzzles to solve. Smart animals are depressed 
when they don't have any activity that makes their brain works. (this is 
why stupid dogs are said to make better family pets, while smart dogs are 
much happier being co-workers and assistants)
comments.author: tenedria
